chapter: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is overexpressed in patients diagnosed with glioma?
questions.explanation:
Gliomas show overexpression of PDGF- and TGF-. Isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) wild-type glioblastomas are associated with epidermal growth 
factor receptor (EGFR) amplification and homozygous CDKN2A deletion.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is associated with loss of function mutation in RET proto-oncogene?
questions.explanation:
Loss of function mutation in RET proto-oncogene is associated with Hirschsprung's disease. Hirschsprung's disease is caused by mutations in other genes encoding proteins involved in 
enteric neurodevelopment. These include: • RET ligand glial-derived neurotrophic factor • Endothelin • Endothelin receptor Note: Medullary thyroid carcinoma and multiple endocrine neoplasias, types 2A and 2B are 
usually due to gain of function mutations in RET proto-oncogene.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following tumors is associated with mutation of the ALK receptor?
questions.explanation:
Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) is a membrane-bound receptor tyrosine kinase. When 
aberrantly expressed, it is associated with neuroblastoma pathogenesis. It serves as a therapeutic 
target. Neuroblastoma is one of the most common solid cancers among children.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question:
Question 4: A 60-year-old man presents with a painless loss of vision. Fundus examination reveals the 
lesion shown in the image. Which of the following GTP-binding proteins show point 
mutations in this condition? 216 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and fundus examination are suggestive of uveal melanoma which is associated 
with a point mutation of GNAQ protein or GNA11 genes. Uveal melanomas (UM) originate from melanocytes in the interior wall of the eye. This includes 
the iris, ciliary body, and the choroid with marked differences in light exposure (from dark 
anterior to illuminated posterior). GNAS mutation causes pituitary adenoma and other endocrine tumors. 225 
Sold by @itachibot The 3 RAS genes in humans (H-RAS, K-RAS, and N-RAS) are the most common oncogenes in 
human cancer. They code for a family of proteins called GTP-binding (G) proteins, which are 
involved in transmitting signals within cells (cellular signal transduction). When RAS is 'switched 
on' by incoming signals, it subsequently switches on other proteins, which ultimately results in 
cell growth, differentiation, and survival. Mutations in RAS genes can lead to the production of permanently activated RAS proteins. As a 
result, this can cause unintended and overactive signaling inside the cell, even in the absence of 
incoming signals. Because these signals result in cell growth and division, overactive RAS 
signaling can ultimately lead to cancer.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following are coded by the MYC genes?
questions.explanation:
MYC oncogene codes for nuclear regulatory proteins. It is the most commonly involved 
transcription factor in tumors. The MYC proto-oncogene MYC activates the expression of many genes that are involved in cell 
growth. It upregulates the expression of telomerase and reprograms somatic cells into pluripotent 
stem cells.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is associated with the translocation of cyclin D1?
questions.explanation:
Translocation of cyclin D1 is seen in mantle cell lymphoma. Mantle cell lymphoma is an uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that is characterized 
by overexpression of cyclin D1. It is a type of non Hodgkins lymphoma that involves (11;14) 
translocation i.e. between IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 
11.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is false about Knudson's two-hit hypothesis theory on retinoblastoma?

options.a: Familial type is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait
options.b: It involves both alleles of RB at chromosome locus 13q14
options.c: In sporadic cases, both normal RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same
options.d: In familial cases, children inherit one defective copy of the RB gene and the other copy is

questions.explanation:
Retinoblastoma is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. Knudson's hypothesis, also known as the two-hit hypothesis or multiple-hit hypothesis states that 
cancer is the result of accumulated mutations in a cell's DNA. Two mutations (hits), involving both 
alleles of RB at chromosome locus 13q14, are required to produce retinoblastoma. In familial cases, children inherit one defective copy of the RB gene in the germline (the first hit), 
and the other copy is normal. Retinoblastoma develops when the normal RB allele is mutated in 
retinoblasts as a result of a spontaneous somatic mutation (the second hit). Most individuals 
inheriting a germline defect in one RB allele develop unilateral or bilateral retinoblastoma as it is 
an autosomal dominant disease. Sporadic cases are comparitively rare. In sporadic cases, both normal RB alleles must undergo 
somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two hits). The image given below shows the Knudson's two-hit hypothesis. 226 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 8: If the RB gene is hypophosphorylated, which of the following will happen?

options.a: Cell cycle will stop at G2
options.b: Cell cycle will stop at G1
options.c: There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed
options.d: The cell cycle progresses and cell divides

questions.explanation:
If the retinoblastoma (RB) gene is hypophosphorylated, it is active and the cell cycle will stop at 
G1. RB is a cell-cycle regulator because it binds to and inactivates a transcription factor (E2F). This is 
necessary for the transcription of certain genes necessary for the progression from the G1 to S 
phase. The phosphorylation of RB results in the release of E2F. This activates gene transcription 
and cell-cycle progression occurs. The image given below shows the cell cycle regulation by RB gene. 227 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following statements is false about p53?

options.b: P53 inactivation causes cell cycle arrest at G2-M
options.c: Cancers demonstrate biallelic loss of function mutations in TP53
options.d: p53 can be inactivated by E6 protein of HPV

questions.explanation:
P53 is the tumor suppressor gene and activation (not inactivation) causes cell cycle arrest at 
the G1-S and G2-M phase of the cell cycle. P53 regulates: • Cell cycle progression • DNA repair • Cellular senescence • Apoptosis It is activated by: • Anoxia • Inappropriate signaling by mutated oncoproteins • DNA damage It is the most frequently mutated gene in cancers. It upregulates the expression of proteins such 
as the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p21, thereby causing cell-cycle arrest at the G1-S. It 
also transactivates and transrepresses target gene to induce G2/M arrest. Mutation in the p53 
gene causes resistance in tumors to radiation and chemotherapy. The E6 protein of human papillomavirus (HPV) binds to and helps in the degradation of p53 and 
stimulates the expression of telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT), which is the catalytic 
subunit of telomerase, thereby helping in the longevity of the cells. E6 from high-risk HPV types 
has a higher affinity for p53 than E6 from low-risk types. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder due to a defect in the tumor 
suppressor gene P53 located on chromosome 17.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is essential for the differentiation of stratified squamous epithelia?
questions.explanation: p63 is essential for the differentiation of stratified squamous epithelia. p53 is ubiquitously expressed, while p63 and p73 show more tissue specificity. p73 has strong pro-apoptotic effects after DNA damage induced by chemotherapeutic agents.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question:
Question 11: A 22-year-old man was found to have multiple GI polyps. He was operated on for thyroid 
cancer 2 years back. His family history is significant for breast cancer in his mother and 
endometrial cancer in his aunt. Germline loss-of-function mutations of which gene is 
associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of Cowden syndrome. This condition is caused due to germline 
loss of function mutation in PTEN (phosphatase and tensin homolog) gene. PTEN is a membrane-associated phosphatase encoded by a gene on chromosome 10q23 that is 
mutated. Cowden syndrome is characterized by skin appendage tumors and an increased incidence of 
epithelial cancers, particularly of the breast, endometrium, and thyroid. 228 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question:
Question 12: A 24-year-old woman presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. MRI was done and showed 
the presence of bilateral acoustic schwannomas. Which protein involved in cytoskeletal 
stability is mutated in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and MRI findings are suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF-2). Merlin 
protein is mutated in NF-2, sporadic schwannomas, and meningiomas. Cells lacking Merlin do not establish stable cell-to-cell junctions. They are insensitive to normal 
growth arrest signals generated by cell-to-cell contact.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 13: Germline loss-of-function mutation of which gene causes Gorlin syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Germline loss-of-function mutations of the PTCH1 gene cause Gorlin syndrome. Gorlin syndrome is an autosomal-dominant disorder. Clinical features include: • Multiple basal cell carcinomas • Highly characteristic facies - large forehead • Bifid or misshapen ribs • Vertebral and other skeletal anomalies • Pits of the skin of the palms and soles • Dysgenesis of the corpus callosum • Calcification of the falx cerebri - at an earlier age than is seen in non■affected individuals • Macrocephaly Acquired biallelic loss-of-function mutations of PTCH1 cause sporadic basal cell carcinomas and 
medulloblastoma.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question:
Question 14: A 25-year-old man patient presents with anemia and abdominal pain. On examination, he has 
pigmented macules over the palms, soles, and oral mucosa. Further investigations reveal 
loss-of-function mutations of the STK11 gene. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of Peutz–Jeghers syndrome. Loss-of-function mutations of STK11 cause the Peutz–Jeghers syndrome. The STK22 gene, also 
known as LKB1, encodes a serine/threonine kinase that is an important regulator of cellular 
metabolism. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal-dominant disorder. It is associated with arborizing 
polyps of the gastrointestinal tract (small intestine > colon > stomach). It increases the risk 
of multiple epithelial cancers, particularly of colon, breast, lung, pancreas, and thyroid.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question:
Question 15: A 38-year-old woman presents with complaints of a palpable mass in both breasts. 
Histopathology examination shows the following finding. Immunohistochemistry showed 
estrogen receptor positivity. Which protein that maintains cell adhesion, and thereby inhibits 
cell motility, is mutated in this condition?
questions.explanation:
229 
Sold by @itachibot The given scenario is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast which involves 
mutated E-cadherin protein. In this condition, the histopathological examination 
shows infiltrating small monomorphic discohesive tumor cells arranged in 
an Indian-file or single-file pattern. The image below shows the single file pattern seen in lobular carcinoma of the breast. Reduced cell surface expression of E-cadherin is seen in carcinomas of: • Breast • Esophagus • Colon • Ovary • Prostate E-cadherin is a cell-surface protein that maintains intercellular adhesiveness. Loss of E-cadherin 
causes disaggregation of cells, which can then invade locally or metastasize. Germline loss-of-function mutations of the E-cadherin gene lead to familial gastric 
carcinoma. Sporadic gastric carcinomas are also associated with the loss of E-cadherin expression.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the BRCA genes?

options.a: BRCA1 is located on the long arm of chromosome 17
options.d: BRCA 2 mutation is associated with male breast carcinoma

questions.explanation: BRCA2 (not BRCA 1) mutation causes well-differentiated cancer.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is incorrect regarding apoptosis?

options.a: p53 induces apoptosis in cells with DNA damage
options.b: Extrinsic apoptotic pathway is more frequently disabled in cancer cells
options.c: Chemoradiation induces apoptosis in cancer cells
options.d: BCL2 is over-expressed in follicular lymphomas

questions.explanation:
The intrinsic apoptotic pathway is most frequently disabled in cancer cells to evade cell death. 230 
Sold by @itachibot p53 is an important pro-apoptotic protein that induces apoptosis in cells that are unable to repair 
DNA damage. Chemotherapy and radiation therapy kills cancer cells mainly by inducing apoptosis via the 
intrinsic pathway. In greater than 85% of follicular B-cell lymphomas, the anti-apoptotic gene BCL2 is overexpressed 
due to a (14;18) translocation.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following genes promote epithelial-mesenchymal transition in epithelial 
tumors?
questions.explanation:
SNAIL and TWIST, which encode transcription factors, promote epithelial-to-mesenchymal 
transition (EMT). In EMT, carcinoma cells downregulate certain epithelial markers (e.g., E-cadherin) and upregulate 
certain mesenchymal markers (e.g. vimentin and smooth muscle actin). This favors the 
development of a promigratory phenotype that is essential for metastasis. EMT has been 
documented mainly in breast carcinoma.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is a non-receptor tyrosine kinase?
questions.explanation:
ABL is a non-receptor tyrosine kinase. Tyrosine kinases may be receptors and non-receptors. Nonreceptor tyrosine kinases normally localize to the cytoplasm or the nucleus. These are: • ABL - translocation causes CML and point mutation causes ALL • JAK mutation - seen in polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, and myelofibrosis as well 
as other myeloproliferative disorders Receptor tyrosine kinases: • VEGFR • PDGFR • EGFR In chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and some acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the ABL 
gene is translocated from its normal abode on chromosome 9 to chromosome 22 where it fuses 
with the BCR gene forming the Philadelphia chromosome. The resultant chimeric gene encodes a 
constitutively active, oncogenic BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 21: Mutation in which of the following oncogenes can serve as a tumor antigen?
questions.explanation:
RAS is an oncogene that undergoes mutation and serves as a tumor antigen. Tumor cells express antigenic molecules on their surface that elicit an immune response. These 
are called tumor antigens. Some tumor cells evade immune response which results in growth of 
the tumor.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following mechanisms does not lead to immune evasion by the tumor cells?

options.a: Inhibition of PD-1 receptor on T-cells

questions.explanation:
Inhibition of PD-1 receptor (programmed death -1 receptor) on T cells causes activation of 
immunity against the tumor cells, not evasion. PD-1 receptors present on T cells inhibit T-cell activation. This allows tumors to evade the host 
immunity by the upregulation of the expression of factors like PD-L1 and PD-L2, which act on 
PD-1 receptors.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question:
Question 23: An 8-year-old girl is referred with recurrent blistering rashes over the face and upper limbs 
which worsened following exposure to sunlight. There is a history of similar skin lesions in 
her family and 2 of her uncles were diagnosed with skin cancers at young ages. Examination 
reveals the presence of multiple lentigos and xerosis. What is the likely pathological 
mechanism of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is caused by a defect in the 
DNA nucleotide excision repair pathway resulting in inability to repair pyrimidine dimers. 232 
Sold by @itachibot Clinical features of xeroderma pigmentosum: • Actinic keratosis • Hyperkeratotic lesions • Multiple lentigos • ùerosis • Corneal scarring The image of a child with xeroderma pigmentosum is given below.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question:
Question 24: Which of the following disorders is not associated with defective homologous recombination 
DNA repair mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Fanconi syndrome is not associated with defective homologous recombination DNA repair 
mechanism. It is a rare disorder of kidney tubule function. Diseases with defects in DNA repair by homologous recombination: • Bloom syndrome and ataxia–telangiectasia triggered by DNA-damaging agents such as ionizing 
radiation • Fanconi anemia is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in multiple genes 
responsible for coding for proteins that participate in DNA repair pathways and are triggered by 
DNA-crosslinking agents like chemotherapeutic drugs. • Familial breast cancer is due to inherited gene defects in BRCA1 and BRCA 2 genes
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question:
Question 25: A 30-year-old patient presents with right iliac fossa pain. Imaging shows the presence of an 
ileocaecal mass. Biopsy of the mass shows a starry sky pattern. What is the translocation 
involved in this tumor?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history and biopsy findings are suggestive of Burkitt lymphoma and the 
translocation involved is t(8;14). 233 
Sold by @itachibot Burkitt lymphoma, also known as small non-cleaved-cell lymphoma, is a highly aggressive B-cell 
non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-myc 
gene on chromosome 8. The classic t(8;14)(q24;q32) reciprocal translocation results in the transposition of the c-myc 
proto-oncogene on chromosome 8 with one of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) genes on 
chromosome 14. This results in activation of the c-myc gene and is considered responsible for 
tumor proliferation.
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 26: Which epigenomic regulatory gene is mutated in most of the follicular lymphomas?
questions.explanation:
MLL2 is an epigenomic regulatory gene that is mutated in most follicular lymphomas. It results in 
histone methylation. Epigenetics refers to factors other than the sequence of DNA that regulate gene expression. These 
factors involved in epigenetics are: • Histone modifications • DNA methylation • Nucleosome positioning/ chromatin remodeling
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question: Question 27: The loss of which of the following micro RNAs leads to upregulation of BCL-2?
questions.explanation:
The loss of miR-15 leads to upregulation of the anti-apoptotic protein BCL-2. miR-15 and miR-16 are tumor-suppressive miRNAs involved in chronic lymphocytic leukemia 
(CLL). Onco-miRNAs include: 234 
Sold by @itachibot • miR200 - promotes epithelial-mesenchymal transitions that promote tumor invasion and 
metastasis • miR155 - involved in human B-cell lymphomas
questions.chapter_heading: Molecular Basis of Cancer and Tumor Immunity

questions.question:
Question 28: Identify the correct statement regarding immune surveillance. 223 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Anti-CTLA-4 antibody ipilimumab was the first drug to achieve a significant improvement in 
survival of advanced-stage melanoma. Cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen 4 (CTLA-4) plays an 
important inhibitory role in the control of T-cell activation. Ipilimumab is a fully-humanized IgG1 monoclonal antibody that inhibits cytotoxic T lymphocyte 
antigen-4 (CTLA-4). It has been postulated that anti-CTLA-4 antibodies act by blocking inhibitory signals from effector 
T-cells, allowing costimulatory signaling and generation of antitumor T-cell responses. In vitro 
studies demonstrated also that the antitumor activity of CTLA-4 blockade is mediated by Fc 
gamma receptor-expressing macrophage and hypothesized a possible role of regulatory T-cell 
depletion in the tumor microenvironment. Option B - Mutation of tumor supressor genes is associated with increased risk of cancer. Antigen 
toxicity is when the immune response to an antigen is excessive or misdirected, causing damage to 
tissues or organs. Option C - PD1/PDL1 is an immune checkpoint whose activation inhibits T-cell function and helps 
with immune tolerance. Blocking PD-1/PD-L1 interaction using immune checkpoint inhibitors 
reactivates T cells and enhances immune responses against tumors. Option D - CD28 is primarily involved in providing the second signal required for T cell 
activation. The first signal comes from the interaction between the T cell receptor (TCR) and the 
antigen presented by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on antigen-presenting cells 
(APCs). Without CD28-mediated costimulation, T cells that only receive the TCR signal (without 
the second signal) can become anergic. 235 
Sold by @itachibot Carcinogenesis, Paraneoplastic Syndromes and Tumor Markers
